NOTE 1:Also see my Company of Heroes Review here:http://steamcommunity.com/id/miyumiayase/recommended/4560And my Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts here:http://steamcommunity.com/id/miyumiayase/recommended/9340NOTE 2:Normally I would give this expansion a 'Not Recommended' rating but since a 'Complete Pack' exists I highly advice that you buy the aforementioned Pack to have the full Company of Heroes 1 experience.TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Company of Heroes: Tales of Valor is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ (RIP). This game serves as the second official expansion pack to the series which adds new game types that focuses on micro-management of either a single or small unit sizes, new 'Direct Fire' ability, new mini-campaigns which rewards you with alternate unit models for certain factions and fun new multiplayer modes.The expansion pack 'Tales of Valor' gives the players three new mini-campaigns. The first one is 'Tiger Ace' which lets the players control a rampaging Tiger I Tank in a small town. The story follows the exploits of Majorgeneral Voss (character from Opposing Fronts) and Hauptmann Schultz (main antagonist of the first game). The second mini-mission is 'Causeway' where the player takes command of a group of paratroopers of the 86nd Air Division in their efforts to secure and hold the La Fiere Causeway which was being used by Allied forces to pass through the Normandy beaches. The last and final mini-mission is 'Falaise Pocket' where the player controls a renegade SS Panzergrenadiers and Wehrmacht soldiers who were ordered to evacuate but defied High Command in order to hold off advancing allied forces and give time for retreating German troops to escape.PROS:+ New missions are fun to play+ New units looks nice but... (See CON # 2)+ New and fun multiplayer game modes like 'Stonewall'+ Micromanagement gameplay (specially with the 'Tiger Ace' mission) was very fun+ 'Falaise Pocket' mission was extreme+ Artwork cutscenes were nice and complemented with good voice actingCONS:- No new armies or units- Some new units are just skin replacements- Mini-campaigns can be completed in a few hours for all three missions (I didn't expect it to be as long as the original campaign or as long as the Opposing Fronts campaign but I didn't imagine that it was this short)- The 'Directed Fire' feature is very hard to use and is implemented badly- Tried to do Stealth missions which were implemented (just like the above CON) badly- This expansion feels rushedCONCLUSION:Much like a Sherman to a Tiger Tank, this expansion is vastly inferior to the other games. It has its moments with some really intense battles particularly the 'Falaise Pocket' campaign, interesting new game mechanics from 'Tiger Ace' and cool looking replacement units but in the end, it doesn't really add anything innovative to the title. Playing through the campaign missions will leave players feeling that this expansion was rushed and released prematurely.Normally I would give this expansion a 'Not Recommended' rating but since a 'Complete Pack' exists I highly advice that you buy the aforementioned pack to have the full Company of Heroes 1 experience.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? 												The entire Company of Heroes collection is a great RTS, especially for those who traditionally don't like to play this genre of game due to the punishing difficulty on new players (seen in the big name ones, like StarCraft). The fact that this is a World War 2 setting will also draw out some people to try the game out.CoH doesn't have you building your base and gathering resources, rather it has you capturing points on the maps which provide you with increased resources and army capacity. This lets you worry more about managing position on the battlefield, rather than managing how many drones you have collecting resources. As you play more, you will see little nuances of the game that make the game deeper and more complex, like cover behind walls, flanking, and all the sorts of things you may expect from playing an in-depth, turn-based, strategy game.Overall, the CoH collection of games have a great single player campaign experience, and a thriving multiplayer community. If you like real-world settings for war, this RTS is probably for you.Tales of Valor has a much weaker single-player experience than the previous entries. It's really just more of the same, but with a bit taken out. Regardless, it is still worthwhile to have if you are a CoH fan.6/10 "Okay"

												Anyone who knows me knows what I think about this game. It's an RTS that does a lot of things differently from the Starcraft/C&C crowd, with brilliant new ideas that make for excellent gameplay. It is, bar none, my favorite RTS of all time.Resource income is based on control of territory sectors distributed all over the map. Your economy hinges on being proactive and willing to fight to push the front line forward. Turtling in your base is effectively forfeiting the match.Combat is more nuanced -- less about reflexes and more about tactics. Reading the terrain and making use of environmental cover is a vital skill. Flanking, formations, suppression, combined-arms assaults... very few of these concepts matter in most RTS games of today, but they're all here and all important components of victory in CoH.I don't know if this game is ever going on sale again, but if you have money to spend, get this game. You'll get a fresh, masterfully-crafted experience, and countless hours of fun in online matches alongside, or against, your friends.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												The game in of itself has both good and bad, but mostly bad.  If you want to get it for a riveting single-player focused on the struggle and chaos of the second half of WW II, you sort of get it.  Most of the ‘characters’ if you even want to call them that blandly spit out their lines as they send another wave of conscripts with the game-equivalent of a BB gun against armored cars and tanks.  Don’t expect a story as in-depth or well-paced as “Saving Private Ryan.”  If that’s not your cup of tea, then fine.  If you want shooty-shooty tanky-tanky then this is the place for it.  Most of the game leans on its multiplayer for any sense of replay-ability, as the ‘medals’ you work to earn in the campaign aren’t even a challenge, and you can generally acquire them without even realizing you did (by the third sweep of the 5-hour campaign, I had it to 100% completion.)The problem with multiplayer is that it’s completely dead.  That’s all I can really say.  I don’t know if there’s a hyper-elite community of the game’s veterans that shun nooby outsiders or if it’s flooded with bad players because the game on sale day is cheaper than dirt.  I never found a lobby, never conversed with anyone, nothing.  The HD re-release of Age of Empires 2 has a larger following than this, for goodness’ sake.  So with no multiplayer and a luke-warm single player, skirmish mode is your best bet, where you place yourself against the AI on a whole slew of different maps that inevitably (and I mean completely without failure) turn into ‘who has more tanks?’  Oftentimes it’s the Wehrmacht (the primary German army) and their best pals the Panzer-Lehr division (given you have the other DLC).  If you play as American (as their campaign is the longest and you’ll have much more experience with them) enjoy getting smacked around considering all your truly good units (Shermans, Rangers, Hellcats/ Wildcats) don’t show up until way late game when the enemy’s already busting up you and your incompetent allies with Jagpanthers, King Tigers, Hetzers, Stugs, StuH42’s, or whatever else they feel like. Speaking of the A.I, if your faction is the Allies you get a choice between Americans or Brits, Axis being Wehrmacht or Panzer-Lehr, which sounds diverse, and in some cases is, but they are completely brain dead.  The securing of territory (marked by capturing certain points on the map) is what allows you to gain more resources and ultimately win.  In the one of two skirmish modes, some of these points are replaced with special ‘victory points’ which you capture and hold in order to drain your enemy’s points to zero.  Oftentimes my allies would capture a territory one of these points was within, build up their forward base, send units, bring in gliders, whatever, and never even touch the victory point.  Didn’t matter if we were behind or ahead; they were that dense.  And lord forbid you set the enemy difficulty above ‘normal’ because they will stomp you and your allies into the dirt with the fun little process I can only refer to as cheating.  You will be stampeding through their base with your vastly superior Shermans, Rangers, and armored divisions only for them to call in special units from their command tree and push you back effortlessly.  If I could describe this game in one word, it’d be frustrating.6/10.  Buy it if it’s on sale for good and cheap so you don’t feel that cheated when you realize how crap it really is after a while.

												Please note that I am not recommending this game based on it being £9.99 in the store.  Depending on future sales, it may be worth a look if you are a company of heroes fan.My main beef with this is the length of the campaigns.  You will see that I have played this game for 3 hours, which is the total length of time it has taken for me to complete all three campaigns on a normal difficulty setting.  There is some replay value in attempting to achieve some of the medals for secondary objectives but I would not envisage this taking more than about another hour of gameplay.  So £9.99 for three hours of game play, I don't feel that's value for money.The original Company of Heroes was/is an exceptional game that rightfully is considered to be one the greatest RTS games ever made.  This game seems to run on the same engine and is a stand alone game to the original so you don't need that to play it.  There are three campaigns, though I use that word in the loosest sense as none of them are very long, all centred around the campaign in Normandy.  Each campaign consists of three missions which are all on the same map (to be clear there are three maps, one for each campaign).  There are two German campaigns and one US campaign.  The first campaign has you in control of one (yes one) Tiger tank for two of the missions, gaining a second for the final mission.  This is a relatively quick but somewhat stale campaign as you're normally used to managing a number of units in combined operations.  The designers (in a nod to Men of War) have also included a direct fire command so you can target enemy units directly with the mouse.  This feature didn't really add anything to the game for me and felt tacked on.The second campaign has you controlling two US squads with an expanded force later on.  This is slightly more challenging although I question the results of some of the combat as they seem to be 'super soldiers'.  This is challenging given that you are fighting with infantry against vehicles and infantry in fortifications with artillery support.The third campaign is much better and has you defending a town (Chambois) at the base of the Falaise gap as the German's against relentless Allied ground and air assault.  This is more like the classic Company of Heroes, requiring you to cotrol sectors, build defences, recruit different troop types and muster a defence against a superior enemy.  This for me was the most challenging and enjoyable campaign and one I will play again.I haven't played multiplayer but there a number of different units that change the unit roster for the various countries.  I can't comment directly but I'm not sure that having an amphibious kubelwagen really adds that much beyond novelty!I feel that Opposing Fronts adds much more for the single player and multiplayer and if you haven't got that then I'd go for that one first.I add that I got this game for free in a PC Gamer magazine so for value I'd say that about £0.50 to £1.50 is what I would pay for this.

												To be perfectly clear: this is a review for the New Steam Version of CoH.Company of Heroes is probably my most beloved franchise of all time. So why am I giving this a negative review?Here's what happened: CoH's original publisher, THQ, went bankrupt and CoH and its development house were sold to Sega. Multiplayer infrastructure is now handled natively through Steam. This sounds great in theory, but in practice, the game suffers from constant, crippling crashes. It really is unplayably bad. It's unconscionable that things could have been allowed to deteriorate so badly, but I suppose it was inevitable that such an old game wouldn't get the love it needed. The gameplay and graphics really do hold up quite well: in fact I'd say it bests CoH 2 in practically all regards.What a sad and ignominious way for a beautiful game to live out its last days. CoH really didn't deserve to go out with a whimper. If you haven't played the single-player campaigns, you really owe it to yourself to play through the original and Opposing Fronts campaigns, which are brilliant. But as for multiplayer, this game is essentially over, barring the unlikely event that the netcode is ironed out to pre-Steam levels.Fare ye well, CoH.

												If you enjoy military RTS games, then you will love this game.Well balanced, and even handed - one of my pet annoyances within this genre is how the AI will magically 'know' where your units are, or move out of an incoming artillery barrage for no apparent reason, or tanks that have excellent visibility when buttoned down, etc.Happily, there is little evidence of AI advantage in this game, which gives an indication of the thought put into the game by the designers - they have actively programmed in real world constraints, rather than be lazy and not balance the AI, like so many other games in this genre.Gameplay is easy to pickup, giving newcomers and old hands a smooth introduction into the game. From there, expect to have the hours stolen away from you, as your men valiantly fight off or through Panzers and infantry.Well crafted game, with plenty of replayability, and with it frequently on sale, there is little excuse not to have this fine game in your collection.
